channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Nations Approve Landmark Climate Accord in Paris
item.description: The deal, which required unanimous approval by delegates from around the world, will for the first time commit nearly every country to lowering greenhouse gas emissions.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Representatives of the “high-ambition coalition,” including Foreign Minister Tony de Brum of the Marshall Islands, left, wore lapel pins made of dried coconut fronds, a symbol of Mr. de Brum's country.

item.title: News Analysis: Climate Accord Is a Healing Step, if Not a Cure
item.description: By highlighting the gulf between humanity’s stated goals and its plans to achieve them, the climate deal may spur a more intensive worldwide push.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: A replica of the Earth being photographed during the conference, which ended Saturday.

item.title: Obama, Once a Guest, Is Now a Leader in World Talks
item.description: President Obama declared victory at home in his quest for an ambitious climate agreement, six years after a climate pact in Copenhagen left many disappointed.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Senegal, a Peaceful Islamic Democracy, Is Jarred by Fears of Militancy
item.description: Authorities in Senegal, a Muslim nation that has remained free from violent extremism, fear the groups like Boko Haram are gaining sympathizers.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Muslim religious leaders in Guédiawaye, Senegal, where two women were recently arrested, accused of ties to radical Islamists.

item.title: Political Violence in Burundi Exacts Growing Toll
item.description: Dozens of bodies, some with their hands tied behind their backs, were strewn across the streets of Bujumbura, the capital, on Saturday, a day after coordinated strikes by unidentified gunmen.
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON
item.media:description: A body found in Bujumbura on Saturday. Bodies were strewn throughout the capital; it was not known who was responsible.

item.title: Fallout: Paris Accord Considers Climate Change as a Factor in Mass Migration
item.description: The large-scale displacement of people as a product of global warming has been an ominous, politically sensitive undercurrent at the two-week conference.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants at a shelter on Lesbos, in Greece, last month. Droughts and conflicts caused by climate change are fueling migration.

item.title: Highlights: Agreement’s Careful Language on Curbing Emissions
item.description: The text of the climate pact establishes a commitment by 195 countries to take concrete measures to reel in planet-warming carbon emissions.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Activists arrived on bikes to form a giant banner on Saturday during a demonstration near the Arc de Triomphe in Paris, ahead of a landmark 195-nation deal.

item.title: Fearful, Haitian Migrants Flee Dominican Republic for Camps Along Border
item.description: Fleeing the Dominican Republic by force or by fear, nearly 3,000 Haitian migrants have arrived as stateless refugees to the packed camps of a borderland where cholera thrives and food is scarce.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Families wash clothes in the river that runs by Tête à l’Eau, Haiti, where many who fled the Dominican Republic have settled.

item.title: Saudi Elections Are First to Include Women as Voters and Candidates
item.description: The elections for members of local councils across the kingdom marked the first time that women were able to participate — as both voters and candidates.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Women left a polling place in Riyadh on Saturday. The municipal elections were the first time that women were able to vote.

item.title: Protesters Are in Agreement as Well: Pact Is Too Weak
item.description: Even as a final draft of an agreement was reached, crowds made clear their belief that it would take much more than those measures to halt global climate change.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and ELIAN PELTIER
item.media:description: A demonstration near the Arc de Triomphe in Paris on Saturday to show support for actions against climate change.

item.title: Negotiations Break Down Between Two Koreas
item.description: No progress on long-simmering disputes, from tourism to reunions for family members separated by war and rigid borders many decades ago.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: The Graying Thieves Who Nearly Got Away With a Record Heist in London
item.description: The men behind the biggest burglary in English legal history — worth as much as $30 million — were done in by an old blunder: bragging about it.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The entrance to Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Ltd. in London, where millions of dollars worth of jewels, gold, precious stones and cash were stolen in April. The safe deposit company has since been forced into liquidation.

item.title: North Korean Band Abruptly Leaves China, Its Concerts Canceled
item.description: No reason was given for the cancellation of the shows by the all-female Moranbong Band, whose visit had been widely seen as an gesture aimed at improving ties.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Doctors Without Borders Raises Death Toll in Kunduz Strike to 42
item.description: The number of those killed in a U.S. airstrike that destroyed ae hospital in Kunduz wash higher than previously thought, the medical organization said.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: An employee of Doctors Without Borders inspecting damage after a United States airstrike on the organization's hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan.

item.title: Fighting in Kabul’s Diplomatic Quarter Ends, Afghan Officials Say
item.description: Six police officers, two of them Spanish, were killed battling the insurgents who seized a guesthouse near the Spanish Embassy, officials said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and JAWAD SUKHANYAR
item.media:description: A private security guard on Saturday at the scene of overnight fighting with Taliban insurgents near the Spanish Embassy in Kabul.

item.title: Final Draft of Climate Change Accord Expected on Saturday
item.description: The accord would for the first time commit nearly every country to lower their emissions of planet-warming greenhouse gas emissions.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius of France in his office during the climate change conference on Thursday in Le Bourget, near Paris.

item.title: Draft of Climate Pact Is Ready, U.N. Officials Say
item.description: Officials said negotiators in Paris had agreed on new language for a pact that will be presented Saturday to diplomats from 195 nations.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Ban Ki-moon, left, the secretary general of the United Nations, with Laurent Fabius, the foreign minister of France, at the talks.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Why Poland Is Turning Away From the West
item.description: The country is a post-communist success story. So why is it moving away from liberal democracy?
item.dc:creator: IVAN KRASTEV

item.title: Argentina Abandons Pact With Iran to Investigate ’94 Attack at Jewish Center
item.description: The country’s new government said it would not appeal a court’s decision striking down the agreement for a joint investigation.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Qaddafi’s Son Hannibal Is Said to Be Abducted in Lebanon
item.description: The National News Agency said the son, Hannibal Qaddafi, who appeared in a video broadcast on Lebanese television, was seized Thursday by kidnappers.
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Hannibal Qaddafi, youngest son of the ex-leader, in 2010.
